about.tagline: Front-End Development / Visual Design / UX Design
about.bio:
Hiya, my name is Emily! I’m a third year student at UC San Diego, pursuing a degree in Cognitive Science: Human-Computer Interaction and a minor in Computer Science. I love crafting visual experiences and seeing them through to implementation.

Currently, I work as a web developer for UCSD Information Technology Services and am a visual designer and student leader at Design at UCSD.

Other things I do include playing Stardew Valley and consuming alarming amounts of seafood. Full disclosure: I support House Stark, Team Iron Man, and pineapple on pizza.

projects.title: ERGO
projects.description: ERGO is a mobile web app that utilizes environmental interactions to combat the discomfort and injury that results from a sedentary lifestyle.
projects.summary: Our work environments can work against us. Many of us, especially students and office workers, sit our lives away; this has been linked to high blood pressure, obesity, worse mental health, and more. ERGO is a mobile web app that combats the discomfort and injury that results from a sedentary lifestyle by periodically alerting users to stretch. Designed to work across many different environments, including offices, coffee shops, and outdoor spaces, ERGO is unique in that it introduces exercises that utilize the everyday objects around us, inspiring users to rethink their interactions with their spatial environments.

intro.title: Key Skills
intro.content: Design research, needfinding, experience & paper prototyping, user testing, visual design

sections.title: Note
sections.content: ERGO is an ongoing project that will be completed March 2018. Stay tuned!

projects.title: Portfolio
projects.description: Built my portfolio from the ground up to showcase my evolving set of visual design and web development skills.
projects.summary: To showcase my adaptive skill range, I took on the role of both the designer and developer to build my portfolio from the ground up.

intro.title: Skills
intro.content: HTML, CSS, Sass, jQuery, Express + Handlebars

sections.title: Problem
sections.content: As an undergraduate student looking to apply for UI/UX design and engineering internships, an online portfolio was a must-have. The task at hand was to create a simple portfolio website to accompany my resume, where I’d present my projects and provide potential employers easy access to my online platforms. However, I faced an inconvenient situation: I had switched into UC San Diego’s human-computer interaction program at the beginning of my third year. With less formal experience and project courses under my belt than my peers, how do I build a compelling portfolio? If not through UX projects, in what other ways can I convey my understanding of the human-centered design process?

sections.title: Research + Solution
sections.content:
To begin answering these questions, I combed through the portfolios of seasoned UI/UX designers to figure out what made them successful in landing positions. Through this competitive analysis, I confirmed that it was essential to have a strong sense of visual design and a unique brand. The defining characteristic of a solid portfolio, however, was the designer’s ability to communicate their thought process and approach through story. Some of my favorites are amandashearon.com, melaniedaveid.com, and chris-liu.me.

Because storytelling plays such a fundamental role in UX, I decided to include graphic design projects in my portfolio to provide more insight into my process. I particularly chose those that involved branding, as they presented many opportunities for me to walk through my design decisions. While these graphic design projects do not explicitly showcase my UX skills, they illustrate how I use research to derive visual solutions that satisfy client needs.

On top of communicating my understanding of design thinking, I also needed to demonstrate my skill set in both visual design and coding. The solution here was obvious: build my portfolio from scratch.

sections.title: Ideation
sections.content: Content before design. There’s nothing worse than coding an entire website, only to realize at the end that it doesn’t accommodate your content. I knew I’d be including diverse projects in my portfolio, and thus the layout for my case study pages would contain more complex elements. Content I needed to account for included basic text and image sections, but also color palettes and PDFs. Moreover, these sections would be chapters of an overarching story. With this in mind, I began sketching out layouts that had clearly defined content blocks.

sections.title: First Iteration
sections.caption: While the case study layout in my first iteration covered all the bases I defined above, I was uneased with how intrusive my accent color felt. Overall, I was not particularly fond of the direction I was going in, especially with the branding, so I scrapped everything for a fresh start.

sections.title: Final Design
sections.content: As a huge fan of minimal design, I wanted the layout of my portfolio to be clean and simple. I decided the perfect way to achieve this while also expressing my graphic design roots was to draw inspiration from print portfolios and editorial layouts, which often consist of generous white space and creative typography. For my color palette, I stuck with neutrals and used my accent color sparingly to ensure that my projects are centerplace. View mood board

sections.title: Development
sections.content:
Because I am presenting myself as both a designer and developer, it was key that I build my portfolio from scratch. My first time around, I used my self-taught knowledge of Sass, Bootstrap and AngularJS to achieve a smooth, responsive site. My web development skills have since come a long way, and I found my initial code to be messy and inefficient. My portfolio also did not have functionality that benefited from using a framework as complex as AngularJS. After receiving formal education in an interaction design course, I performed a complete overhaul of my website. Tools I used to develop the current version of my portfolio are:

  • Sass
  • Node.js + Express + Handlebars

The biggest change between my first and second iteration was my switch to the Handlebars templating engine. Since the bulk of my portfolio is a set of identically laid out case studies, it was the perfect tool. By templating this page, I significantly reduced clutter and made adding new projects painless. I also wanted my website to be pixel-perfect, so I decided against using Bootstrap to allow for more control. View on Github

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: The final product had an aesthetic brand, incorporated a layout that facilitated storytelling, and was supported by efficient code. Overall, it demonstrates my skill set as a visual designer, UX designer, and front-end developer. I am now ready to apply for internships! :^)

projects.title: How Far I'll Go
projects.description: Created graphics and shirt design for Kaibigang Pilipin@’s 27th annual high school conference.
projects.summary: Themed after the animated Disney film Moana, UCSD Kaibigang Pilipin@'s 27th Annual High School Conference was held February 3rd, 2018. These high school conferences are coordinated in collaboration with the Student Promoted Access Center for Education and Service (SPACES) and aim to empower high school students to pursue higher education. This year, I was invited to create graphics and a shirt design for the event.

projects.title: Ourstory Gala
projects.description: Spearheaded the branding for UCSD Kaibigang Pilipin@’s 30th Anniversary Ourstory Gala, a quinquennial celebration held to commemorate the organization and its accomplishments.
projects.summary: Kaibigang Pilipin@ (KP), translated to "Friendship of Filipin@s," is a student-run organization at UC San Diego that aims to educate the community about Pilipin@ culture. Every five years, KP hosts their Ourstory Gala, a celebration held to commemorate the organization and its accomplishments. I worked closely with the event coordinator to craft a unique identity for their 30th Anniversary Ourstory Gala, themed after the film 13 Going on 30.

sections.title: Ideation + Style Guide
sections.content: What set this Ourstory Gala apart from its predecessors is that it would be a formal event held at The Great Hall, a building with high ceilings and tall glass windows. To create a brand that matched the elegance exuded by the dress code and venue, I decided to pair the classy serif Cormorant Garamond with the delicate Coneria Script. For the color palette, muted spring colors were chosen. These colors embodied the Ourstory Gala's theme of growth while also being not too flashy for a formal event. The spring palette was also ideal for the setting, as the gala would take place in March.

projects.title: We're All In This Together
projects.description: Designed a flyer and program for UCSD Asian Pacific Islander Student Association’s 23rd annual high school conference.
projects.summary: Every year, various student organizations at UC San Diego collaborate with the Student Promoted Access Center for Education and Service (SPACES) to host conferences that empower high school students to pursue higher education and provide them with networking opportunities. The Asian and Pacific-Islander Student Alliance's (APSA) 23rd Annual High School Conference was themed "We're All in This Together," referencing the popular Disney film, High School Musical. As head of the programming committee, I handled the branding for the conference and designed the event flyer and program.
